SI.name: Central Securities Clearing Corporation

wiki_links.title: Agency of the Republic of Slovenia for Public Legal Records and Related Services

SI.wiki_context:
* [http://www.ajpes.si/Default.asp?language=english&mdres=1 Agency of the Republic of Slovenia for Public Legal Records and Related Services (AJPES)] (''pub'', ''reg'') - Official Slovenian company registry is free to access but registration is required. Search is available by the name or ID number of the company for all company types and it gives detailed and historical information. At AJPES, more information is available in Slovenian language compared to the English version. Options in the upper menu: eRTR - data on bank accounts of companies (open, closed) JOLP - annual reports of companies eOBJAVE - insolvency cases w/supporting documentation.

* [http://www-en.kdd.si/ Central Securities Clearing Corporation] (''pub'') - The list of issuers and securities available. Available in English.

* [https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?SLOVENIA&member=1 European Commission E-Justice] (''pub'') - European Commission overview of the Slovenian business registry, including links to the registry, description of how to search and what can be found as well as legislation behind it.

* [http://www.gvin.com/ Gvin (Commercial business registry of Bisnode)] (''paid'', ''reg'') - Search by names of directors/shareholders. Offers all the financial data from annual reports (incl. for years before 2008/2009, which are usually the earliest years you get annual reports for at Ajpes). Info on tax payments, ongoing lawsuits and credit ratings (the latter is a payable service of Ajpes). If a company changed its name, Ajpes would return no results, while Gvin would detect it and put you through to the "new" company. Offers all available documents in one place (except those you can find only at the court register - memorandum/articles of association, insolvency reports, statute). You can click on the address of a company and see what other companies are registered there. Registration and payment required.

* [http://www.oam.si/default_en.aspx?doc=ISSUERS Info Storage] (''pub'') - Contains the list of issuers and the list of securities with company contact information.

* [http://www.ljse.si/cgi-bin/jve.cgi?doc=7026 Ljubljana Stock Exchange] (''pub'') - Search by company name with basic company information. Available in Slovenian.

* [https://e-justice.europa.eu/iri/int... EU Interconnected Insolvency Register (Slovenia)] (''pub'')

* [https://ebr.bundesanzeiger-datenser... European Business Register (Slovenia) -] Access to Slovenian corporate registry via EBR (''paid'', ''reg'')

* [http://www.ajpes.si/ The Slovenian Business Registry] - The name search on the Slovenian Business Registry website returns the registration number, business name and place of operation of a company. More detailed information, such as names of directors and shareholders, can be retrieved after creating a free account with the Registry.

DK.name: Land Registration Court
DK.wiki_context:
===General Company Information (incl. ownership)===

The first site to check for German companies is [https://companyhouse.de]. Sastre has an account on this site, and logging in makes some small improvements to what you can see. This website's layout is easily navigable, so it's good to check for a general overview. However, it's not 100 % reliableespecially for historical information (including establishment date)so any information to be cited in a report should ideally be verified at [https://www.unternehmensregister.de] (see below). Moreover, companyhouse.de tries to charge extra for certain information, such as shareholder details, which can be obtained for free from unternehmensregister.de. **Never buy any filings from companyhouse.de**, because the same documents can all be obtained for free from unternehmensregister.de.

[https://www.unternehmensregister.de] is very tedious to use, but it has lots of great information, all for free. Here's a stepbystep guide to using it for general corporate information (including ownership):

* In the "Schnellsuche" field on the homepage, enter the name of the company you want.

* In the results page, scroll to find the right company and click on **"Registerinformationen des Registergerichts"** next to its name. Note that sometimes the company you want doesn't appear at the top of the results, even if you entered the exact name, so be careful not to accidentally choose the wrong company.

* On the following page, click **"Registerinformationen anzeigen."**

* On the next page, click **"AD"** for a summary of the company's current details ("AD" stands for *aktueller Abdruck*, i.e. "current extract"). For companies with names ending in "KG," this will include ownership information. For other companies, it won't.

* Instead of "AD," you can also click on **"DK"** in order to access specific filings. In the "DK" page, you'll see a "tree" of options with dropdown lists:

* **"Dokumente zur Registernummer"** contains all documents filed while the company has been registered in its current location. If the company has ever been registered in other towns/districts, there will be options for **"bernommene Dokumente"** from previous district courts, i.e. filings submitted while at the old locations.

* The most commonly needed documents from the "DK" view are **shareholder lists** (only available for GmbH companies). A new list is entered whenever there's a change to the shareholder structure. Click on **"Liste der Gesellschafter"** and then choose the document with the most recent date to see the current owners (if there are any without dates, choose those too, in case they're the most recent). The actual document should be selfexplanatory and clearly dated. By downloading all the lists (including from **"bernommene Dokumente,"** where relevant), you can see the full ownership history.

* From the "DK" view you can also access the company's past and current statutes or articles of association under **"Gesellschaftsvertrag / Satzung / Statut,"** as well as other corporate filings that aren't so commonly needed.

* Whether getting a current registry extract ("AD") or specific individual filings ("DK"), unternehmensregister.de works by adding the documents to your **"Dokumentenkorb"** ("document basket"). Where given the option, it's best to choose PDF or TIF format rather than ZIP. Add something to the basket by clicking on **"In den Dokumentenkorb legen."** To actually download the document, you then have to click through several pages: **"Dokumentenkorb ansehen,"** then **"Zur Freischaltung,"** then **"Jetzt freischalten,"** then **"Zum Dokumentenkorb,"** then finally click on the download icon next to each document in your basket.

For crosschecks, you can also consult the **Common Register Portal** of the German Federal States (Handelsregister), which aggregates data from individual state registries. The European Commission's eJustice portal provides an Englishlanguage overview of the German business register and links to the official register.

===Searching for an Individual's Affiliations===

If you want to identify an individual's corporate affiliations, you can search [https://companyhouse.de] by individuals' names (at least if you're logged in with Sastre's account). Individuals' pages on companyhouse.de list all past and current affiliations as a director (**Geschftsfhrer**) or **Prokurist** (authorised signatory), as well as their date of birth and (most recent) place of residence. Ownership relationships aren't usually listed (though occasionally they are, especially for KG companies). The date of birth listed on companyhouse.de is reliable, but the dates of affiliations are very unreliable, so affiliations should ideally be confirmed on unternehmensregister.de as outlined above if you're going to mention them in a report. There's no simple way to search for companies that a person owns; the best approach is to use unternehmensregister.de to check the ownership of any companies where the subject is a director or where you have other reasons to suspect a connection.

===Company Finances===

Official annual financial statements (called *Jahresabschlsse*) are available from both [https://companyhouse.de] and [https://www.unternehmensregister.de]. In terms of the statements' contents, both websites are equally reliableif one website doesn't have a particular year, check the other. On companyhouse.de, go to the **"Jahresabschlsse"** tab on a company's page and choose the statement you want to see. If you're logged into Sastre's account, they should be free to view. On unternehmensregister.de, search a company's name in the **"Schnellsuche"** field. On the results page, for companies that have statements available, each statement is listed beneath the company name (e.g., **"Jahresabschluss zum Geschftsjahr vom 01.01.2010 bis zum 31.12.2010"** for the 2010 report). For older documents or those filed with state registers, you might need to use the **Common Register Portal** or statespecific archives.

===Miscellaneous Notes===

* Ownership information isn't usually available for AG companies, unless they publish it themselves on their website or in their annual reports.

* There's no good way to search for a given company's subsidiaries or shareholdings, but these are sometimes listed in *Jahresabschlsse*.

* **Geschftsfhrer** is best translated as "director" and **Prokurist** as "authorised signatory."

* Regardless of which websites you use to access German corporate records, it's best to cite them as "German corporate records" or similar in your footnotes. Don't link directly to companyhouse.de, which is a thirdparty aggregator.

===Additional Corporate Registry Resources===

* [https://id.occrp.org/databases/#germany OCCRP ID Database for Germany] (''pub'')

* [https://www.handelsregister.de/rp_web/mask.do?Typ=e Common Register Portal of the] German Federal States (''pub'')

* [https://www.firmen-in-berlin.com/sites/fitber/welcome.aspx Companies in Berlin - Business] Database of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCI) Berlin (''pub'')

* [https://beta.e-justice.europa.eu/106/EN/business_registers_in_eu_countries?GERMANY&member=1 European Commission eJustice Overview of] German business registers (''pub'')

* [https://www.deutsche-boerse-cash-market.com/dbcm-de/instrumente-statistiken/statistiken/gelistete-unternehmen Frankfurt Stock Exchange listed companies] (''pub'')

* [http://www.dihk.de/ihk-finder IHKFinder - German Chamber of] Commerce directory (''pub'')

* [https://www.unternehmensregister.de/ureg/?submitaction=language&language=en The German Company Registry (Unternehmensregister)] (''pub'')

* [https://www.bundesanzeiger.de/ebanzwww/wexsservlet Bundesanzeiger - German Federal Gazette] (''pub'')

* [https://www.companyhouse.de/ Companyhouse - third-party corporate registry] service (''paid'')

* [https://www.transparenzregister.de/treg/de/start?1 Transparency Register (UBO register)] (''pub'', ''reg'')  the official register of beneficial owners; access requires registration.

AR.wiki_context:
The [http://www.csjn.gov.ar/ Supreme Court] has available online judgements, agreements and resolutions. The website also includes search engines to look for verdicts by Argentina's other courts. You can look at the most recent verdicts or search them by keyword. The court verdicts are not redacted.

Searches were conducted with the Judicial Power of Argentina Record Information System, Supreme Court of Argentina, Buenos Aires Supreme Court, and Center for Judicial Information of Argentina to identify civil litigation matters involving all applicable subjects. Online records in Argentina may not be comprehensive.

LU.name: '''Cadastre'''] provides real estate records, which can be searched by address only
LU.notes: '''Cadastre'''] provides real estate records, which can be searched by address only (not owner name). Search the target address through the search box, and open the parcel file, which gives basic identification and background details - note that area is measured in hectares (ha), ares (a = 100 m2), and centiares (ca = 1 m2). Detailed local parcel maps from different dates (if available) are listed beneath the background data and accessible in low resolution; full resolution maps can be ordered for free by opening the low resolution map and clicking the link at the bottom of the pop-up box.

EG.wiki_context:
[https://www.cbe.org.eg/en/BankingSupervision/Pages/LicenseLists.aspx Central Bank of Egypt - Licensing Lists]

FINANCIAL COMPANIES

Search the PDF lists for your company.

Note: Sometimes the Arabic language site doesn't work, but English works

The Central Bank of Egypt is the monetary authority in Egypt

The site contains a list of all licensed banks in Egypt as well as their registration dates and financial information that is published in annual reports.

[https://www.efsa.gov.eg/jtags/efsa_ar/index.jsp Egyptian Financial Supervisory Authority]

Step 1:

Internal and site search in English and Arabic

Step 2:

Search RBC Prohibited List

Try to identify reports and decisions published on the website, including administrative sanctions,  control measures, list and profiles of supervised authorities.

[http://www.eeaa.gov.eg/en-us/services/licenses/searchinlistofaccredited.aspx Ministry of Environment - Professional and Environmental Consulting Licensing Services]

[http://www.egypo.gov.eg/ Egypt Patent Office]

[http://www.eca.org.eg/ECA/default.aspx Egyptian Competition Authority]

REQUIRED FOR COMPANIES

Conduct and Internal and Site Search in both Arabic and English.

The ECA is tasked with the Protection of Competition and the Prohibition of Monopolistic Practices to ensure free competition and free entry to and exit from the market.

[https://www.cpa.gov.eg/en-us/ Egyptian Consumer Protection Agency]

REQUIRED FOR COMPANIES

The CPA is the main consumer protection agency of Egypt.

Step 1:Conduct Internal and Site search in both Arabic and English.

Step 2: Conduct the internal Legal Actions Search

[http://www.mcit.gov.eg/ar Egyptian Ministry of Communications and Information]

Conduct and Internal and Site Search in Arabic. This search may provide noteworthy / useful information on your subjects but no derogatory / enforcement type information

[https://www.egypt.gov.eg/english/guide/directory.aspx Additional Database of Industry Specific Ministries]

Search the dropdown for the various sectors and ministries. A site search of one of these ministries may provide useful information on your company / subject

[https://cu.edu.eg/CU_Certificates_Verification Cairo University]

Send an e-mail message to the address on the website for degree verifications.

Key regulators in Egypt include:

GAFI (see above)- regulates free zones in Egypt;

Financial Regulatory Authority, which replaced the Egyptian Insurance Supervisory Authority (EISA), the Capital Market Authority (CMA), and the Mortgage Finance Authority (MFA). It regulates the financial sector;

Public Prosecution Office, which is the office of the attorney general, and has led most investigations into corruption from the Mubarak era in the post-2011 uprising period; and

The Central Bank of Egypt, which sets monetary policy, which has been important over the past decade, since Egypt has a large black market for currency, and suffered a currency shortage after the 2011 uprising.
